721183f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from 23rd to 24th Streets. In the oentre is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building, whose OxDanslon will devour the brownstone church on the left. This is the Madison Suuare Presbyterian Church (1854-1906) from whose pulpit Dr. Charles Parkhurst waged unceasing war on Tammany Hall until that organization was temporarily,at least, overthrown, and its leader, Richard Croker, driven
into exile.
1894.
J. S. Johnston, from Brown Brothers.

721490f.text:
General View:
Fifth Avenue from West 2ird -treet, giving a wide view of 'adison S6,uare, 5th and '~adison
Av nues lookin; north.
Charles e, Ritzman.
NO RiDEODUCTION.  1900.

721185f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side (buildings thereupon), from E. 23rd to 24th Streets as viewed across a corner of Madison Square,from Fifth Avenue. The two office buildings shown are units of the Metropolitan Insurance Co; the larger being the home office prior to tower addition. This feature was constructed on the corner site where the spired Madison Square Presbyterian Church (1854-1906) stands. The domed structure on the opposite corner (N.E. of 24th Street) is being constructed for this congregation and in 1928 will move way for additional offices for the Metropolitan Insurance Co.
December 1905.
Geo. L. Balgue
AEG ~ 3G31

721188f-b.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from E. 23rd (right) to 24th Streets, showing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co. tower under construction at the S. E. corner of the latter point. Upon this site formerly stood the old (1854) Madison Square Presbyterian Church. In the deal for this property the Insurance Co. undertook the replacement of same. That appears at the lower left, opposite its former location. Subsequently (about 1928) this will be replaced by an office building. This in turn (after 1940) will be razed and the site form a corner of a block square structure.

Views 1 and 2 bear no date; No. 3 being photographed October 10, 1908. Note in the earlier photos the Taft and Sherman banner suspended over E. 23rd Street.

In the background is the East River and its Greenpoint shore.

1908
Gift of Urbrook Collection.

C1 - NEG #3637
C2 - NEG #3638
C3 - NEG #3639

721197f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, between E.23rd and E. 24th Streets,showing
Metrepolitan Life lnsurance Building after dark.
Photographer Unknown  about 1908

this is the Woolworth Building, across from City Hall Park, designed by Cass Gilbert, and completed in 1913.

721181f-c.text:
Madison Avenue, north from East 23rd Street, showing Madison Square Park and its surrounding structures at two different stages. The original Madison Souare Garden at 26th Street is being replaced by the New York Life lInsurance Company Building. Note the distinctive Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church (N. E. corner of 24th Street) and the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court (N. E. corner of
25th Street).
Views 1,2: 1908
Views 3,4: September 1928
George L. Balgue

721191f-b.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from East 23rd (right) to 24th Street, showing the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company building and tower and the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. The latter, erected in 1906, was formerly on the corner site where the tower is rising. Expansion of the Insurance Corpany will eventually cause this to be demolished for an office structure and which in turn will be removed for a latter annex that will include the entire
24th to 25th Street block.
View 1: 1908
View 2: October 1914
George L. Balgue

730236f-a.title: General view - [Manhattan - 23rd Street - Madison Avenue (South).]
730236f-a.text:
A general view, south from the Metropolitan Life Iusurance Building. (Hadison Ave., and 223rd St)., showing in the centre, Union Square Park and in the background, at the left, is the East River, with the Manhattan
(first) and Brooklyn (second) Bridges.
About 1909.
Wurts Brothers.

721218f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, south from East 26th to 23rd Streets. At the right is Madison Square, the park that identified this thoroughfare. The Manhattan Club is the ornate structure to the left and adjoins the Madison Square Apartments (street canopy). On the right margin appears a portion of the Fuller (Flatron) Building. The low Hotel Bartholdi
is on the left of the latter.
May 18, 19244
Standard Photographic Service
Gift of Borough President of Manhattan

721219f-a.text:
Madison Avenue, east side, from 2uth to 23rd Streets along Madison Square seen from the west. On N.E. cornen of 26th Street stands the New York Life Building, on the site of the second Madison Square Garden. On S.E. corner of 26th Street the Manhattan Club (old Jerome residence) has been remodelled, balconies removed. At the right is a good view of the Metropolitan tower at 24th Street. This view remains substantially the same in 1935.
1926.
Photograph by Browning Studios.

721223f-b.text:
Madison Ave., at the N.E. corner of East 26th Street (the New York Life Insurance Co. Building) as seen aoross Madison Square Park from
the west side of Fifth Ave. at 25th Street.
July 14, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same structure viewed across the south wes terly
corner of the Park (Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street) from a vantage
point at the base of the Flatiron Building.
Note the silhouetted statue of the Hon. Samuel J. Tilden
in the foreground.
August 5, 1938
George D. Chinn

721205f-b.text:
Madison Avenue, from East 23rd (right) to 26th (left) Street, (buildings thereupon) as photographed across Madison Square Park from 5th Avenue. Prominently shown is the progressive blockwide project conducted by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. This annex will on completion include the entire site from 24th to 25th Streets, and east to 4th Avenue. The remaining structure (N. E. corner of 24th Street), is the office building that replaced the distinguished Madison Square Presbyterian Church. Completed and occupied is the easterly half that fronts on 4th Avenue.
July 18, 1939
Views 1,2,3

P. L. Sperr
